coredata.dc:title: Pigmentation-Independent Susceptibility Loci for Actinic Keratosis Highlighted by Compound Heterozygosity Analysis

coredata.dc:description: Actinic keratosis (AK) is a skin disease frequently found in European elderly, and it represents the precursor of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Our recent genome-wide association study highlighted DNA variants in two pigmentation genes, IRF4 and MC1R, that confer AK risk in Europeans. Here, we performed a genome-wide search for relaxed forms of compound heterozygosity in association with AK using our recently developed software CollapsABEL. In a discovery dataset of 3,193 Dutch Europeans, a total of 15 genetic loci showed genome-wide significant association with AK (P < 1.25 × 10–10). Of those, three loci (6p21.2, 6p12.2, and 6q13) were confirmed in a replication dataset that included 624 additional Dutch Europeans (P < 0.05). These replicated loci harbored six genes (KCNK5/KCNK17, PAQR8/GSTA2, and KCNQ5/KHDC1), none of them known to be involved in pigmentation. A candidate compound heterozygosity analysis for 12 pigmentation loci highlighted SLC24A4 at 14q32.12 as showing significant association with AK (P = 8.83 × 10–9). The four significantly AK-associated compound heterozygosity single-nucleotide polymorphism pairs together explained 4.37% of the total AK variation, which was 2.62 times greater than the two top-associated individual single nucleotide polymorphisms together (1.67%) identified in the previous conventional genome-wide association study. In conclusion, CollapsABEL showed compound heterozygosity in non–pigmentation- and pigmentation-related loci conferring genetic risk of AK.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: GCDH Manhattan plot. GCDH GWAS results are presented as contrast Manhattan plot. All SNPs are represented by dots and displayed per chromosome (x-axis). GCDH-based GWAS results are depicted in green and pink, while outcomes from conventional single SNP GWAS are in blue and purple. The horizontal line indicates threshold of GCDH genome-wide significance, set at 1.25×10-10, and the dashed line indicates the conventional GWAS genome-wide significance threshold 5×10-8. The three replicated loci are annotated in purple. GCDH, generalized collapsed double heterozygosity; GWA, genome-wide association; SNP, single-nucleotide polymorphism.

Regional GCDH. Top SNP pair in (a–c) three replicated loci and (d) the SLC24A4 locus is annotated with corresponding p-value. Dashed arrow points to the position of the second SNP in the pair. Blue curve represents recombination rate, and LD patterns of all SNPs with the first SNP of the pair are graded by color. Chr, chromosome; GCDH, generalized collapsed double heterozygosity; LD, linkage disequilibrium; SNP, single-nucleotide polymorphism.
SNP pairs 1 identified via genome-wide GCDH analysis of AK and replication

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: Abbreviations: β1, β2, effect sizes from discovery and replication datasets; AK, actinic keratosis; EA1, EA2, effect alleles of the SNP pair; fC, frequency of pseudo effect allele for the collapsed genotype; fEA1, fEA2, frequency of effect allele for the SNP pair; GCDH, generalized collapsed double heterozygosity; LD, linkage disequilibrium; Pd, Pr, P-values from discovery and replication datasets; SNP, single-nucleotide polymorphism; SNP1, SNP2, names of the SNP pair.

ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: SNPs are annotated according to the Genome Reference Consortium Human genome build 37 patch release 13 (GRCh37.p13). Significance of the replication P-values are determined by a permutation analysis (number of permutations = 1,000).
AK coded as four ordinal severity levels.
AK coded as the AK count of 0, 2 (median of 1–3), 7 (median of 4–10), 10 to participants belonging to each severity level using the median of each level.
Genes involved: either intronic or intergenic; intronic positions are shown in bold face.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Diplotypes of three replicated SNP pairs and one SNP pair from the SLC24A4 region in association with AK

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: Abbreviations: AK, actinic keratosis; SNP, single-nucleotide polymorphism.

ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: Here we divide the study population into different diplotype groups and compare their average AK levels. In the notation for diplotypes, 1 stands for major allele and 2 for minor, SNPs on the same haplotype are stringed together.
R, reference; I, insertion of an A.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Results of GCDH in a candidate pigmentation gene study 1

ce:legend.ce:simple-para: Abbreviations: GCDH, generalized collapsed double heterozygosity; GWA, genome-wide association; MAF1, MAF2: MAFs of single SNPs; P 1, P 2: P-values of single SNPs; P e, Empirical P-value—the quantile of each P among all P-values produced for SNP pairs in the permutations analysis; P p, P-value of the proband SNP in the single-SNP analysis; SNP, single-nucleotide polymorphism; SNP1, SNP2, names of single SNPs.

ce:table-footnote.ce:note-para: Twelve well-documented human pigmentation-related loci were selected for regional GCDH scan based on significant associations with hair, eye, and/or skin color in previous GWA studies.
The minimal P-value in that region. Threshold of significant was set up by permutation analysis (P = 4.97 × 10–8).

Independent effects of the different predictors and the percentage of explained variance of AK (R 2) were produced by a stepwise multivariable model including age, sex, skin color, four SNP pairs associated with AK, and 12 well-known pigmentation SNPs. Only variables with a P-value < 0.05 were used for calculation of R 2 as shown in the table.

head.ce:title: Pigmentation-Independent Susceptibility Loci for Actinic Keratosis Highlighted by Compound Heterozygosity Analysis

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Actinic keratosis (AK) is a skin disease frequently found in European elderly, and it represents the precursor of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. Our recent genome-wide association study highlighted DNA variants in two pigmentation genes, IRF4 and MC1R, that confer AK risk in Europeans. Here, we performed a genome-wide search for relaxed forms of compound heterozygosity in association with AK using our recently developed software CollapsABEL. In a discovery dataset of 3,193 Dutch Europeans, a total of 15 genetic loci showed genome-wide significant association with AK (P < 1.25 × 10–10). Of those, three loci (6p21.2, 6p12.2, and 6q13) were confirmed in a replication dataset that included 624 additional Dutch Europeans (P < 0.05). These replicated loci harbored six genes (KCNK5/KCNK17, PAQR8/GSTA2, and KCNQ5/KHDC1), none of them known to be involved in pigmentation. A candidate compound heterozygosity analysis for 12 pigmentation loci highlighted SLC24A4 at 14q32.12 as showing significant association with AK (P = 8.83 × 10–9). The four significantly AK-associated compound heterozygosity single-nucleotide polymorphism pairs together explained 4.37% of the total AK variation, which was 2.62 times greater than the two top-associated individual single nucleotide polymorphisms together (1.67%) identified in the previous conventional genome-wide association study. In conclusion, CollapsABEL showed compound heterozygosity in non–pigmentation- and pigmentation-related loci conferring genetic risk of AK.

ce:section.ce:para: Actinic keratosis (AK) is a highly prevalent premalignant skin lesion in European elderly and is generally considered a precursor of invasive squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) (Ruini et al., 2015). Recently, a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on AK identified two well-known pigmentation genes, IRF4 and MC1R, showing genome-wide significant association with AK with successful replications (Jacobs et al., 2015). The top associated single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs1805008 in MC1R and rs12203592 in IRF4 are both relatively common in Europeans (risk allele frequency of ∼0.1), and are both known to be associated with human hair, skin, and/or eye color (Branicki et al., 2011; Han et al., 2008; Liu et al., 2009, 2013, 2015; Sulem et al., 2007; Walsh et al., 2012, 2013). These two SNPs together, however, only explained less than 2% of the phenotypic variance of AK in our previous study (Jacobs et al., 2015). Furthermore, melanogenesis-independent pathways may likely play important roles in the development of AK (Taguchi et al., 1994), suggesting that additional genetic factors exist that remain to be discovered.

Compound heterozygosity (CH) in classical genetics is the presence of two different recessive mutations at a particular genetic locus, one on each chromosome (Schaaf et al., 2011). The presence of CH has been found for nearly all autosomal recessive disorders (Cremers et al., 1998; Pelin et al., 1999; Ward et al., 2002) and for other complex human traits such as red hair color (Liu et al., 2011) and perceived facial age (Liu et al., 2016). As we recently proposed (Zhong et al., 2016), relaxed forms of CH—that is, those not necessarily rare, coding, or deleterious—are likely involved in a wide range of human complex traits including diseases. However, the traditional GWAS approach of testing the association of each SNP separately, as previously applied to AK (Jacobs et al., 2015), may have limited statistical power to detect CH-like associations.

We recently developed an R (R Foundation, https://www.r-project.org) package named CollapsABEL, which is powerful, flexible, and computationally efficient for detecting CH-like associations in GWAS (Zhong et al., 2016). Here, we present an application of CollapsABEL to search for relaxed forms of CH alleles involved in a disease trait, that is, AK.

We used our recently developed software, CollapsABEL (Zhong et al., 2016), to conduct a genome-wide generalized collapsed double heterozygosity analysis of AK. The discovery set consisted of 3,193 and the replication set of 624 subjects (see Supplementary Table S1 online) from the Rotterdam Study (RS). This analysis identified in the discovery set 27 pairs of SNPs at 15 genetic loci showing genome-wide significant association with AK (P < 1.25 × 10–10) (Figure 1 and Table 1 , and see Supplementary Table S2 online). All identified pairs of SNPs were physically close to each other (distance < 500 kbp) and in low linkage disequilibrium (approximated by correlation coefficient, r<0.05) with each other. None of these genetic loci have been found in the previous AK GWAS using the conventional single SNP approach (Jacobs et al., 2015). Using an alternative coding (see Methods section) of AK provided slightly more significant association results (Table 1).

We then conducted a replication analysis of the identified 27 SNP pairs at the 15 genetic loci using the GCDH test in the replication dataset. Three pairs of SNPs at three genetic loci were successfully replicated with P-values lower than 0.05 after adjusting for multiple testing using permutation analysis (Table 1). These include 6p21.2 (rs150757879 at intron of KCNK5, rs115623485 intergenic KCNK5-KCNK17, β = 0.90, P = 0.010), 6p12.2 (rs17650378 intron of PAQR8, rs2608670 intergenic TMEM14A-GSTA2, β = 1.210, P = 0.002), and 6q13 (rs146593174 intron KCNQ5, rs75168318 intergenic KHDC1-DDX43, β = 1.620, P = 0.004). Regional GCDH scans targeting these three replicated loci pick up one new SNP per locus and improve signal strength (rs150757879/rs115623485, P = 2.084 × 10–12; rs17650378/rs2608670, P = 6.118 × 10–14; rs79355720/rs75168318, P = 6.436 × 10–14) (Figure 2 a–c).

We compared the mean of AK between diplotype groups of the three replicated SNP pairs in the combined data set (N = 3,817) (Table 2 ). As expected, individuals carrying the homozygote genotype of either SNP of a pair, as well as the compound heterozygote genotype from both SNPs of a pair, had significantly higher levels of AK than wild-type carriers. For instance, for the SNP pair rs146593174/rs75168318, the two homozygote groups had average AK levels of 1.50 and 2.67, respectively, and that of the compound heterozygote group was 1.89, whereas the average AK levels in all the rest of the diplotype groups were below 0.50. One exception was the SNP pair rs17650378/rs2608670, where the double heterozygote does not appear to be in a compound configuration (Table 2). This is potentially explained by the noted risk allele being in linkage disequilibrium with different diplotypes, which consist of different causal alleles in the compound heterozygote form.

Because two pigmentation genes have previously been shown to significantly associate with AK in the traditional GWAS approach, in which association testing is performed separately for each SNP (Jacobs et al., 2015), we conducted GCDH scans on 12 genomic regions harboring well-known pigmentation genes. This candidate gene GCDH scan (Table 3 and Figure 2d) identified one significant CH-like association (rs192773868/rs116941581 located at 14 q32.12, SLC24A4, P = 8.83 × 10–9) and six suggestive CH-like associations with AK. The significance threshold corrected for multiple testing (5% level) was estimated at P < 4.97 × 10–8 and the suggestive association threshold at P < 6.21 × 10–6 by a permutation analysis (number of permutations = 1,000). Compared with the proband SNP from the previous AK GWAS at the same locus (rs17128291, P = 0.79), there was a significant increase in signal strength, indicating CH interaction in the region. Inferred diplotypes of rs192773868/rs116941581 confirmed that the compound heterozygote group had higher mean AK than other groups (Table 2).

We further conducted a multivariable analysis in the combined dataset, including 19 risk factors of AK: sex, age, skin color, the three AK-associated and replicated CH SNP pairs from GWAS, the one AK-associated CH SNP pair from the pigmentation gene study (SLC24A4), and the 12 pigmentation-related SNPs (proband SNPs) (Table 3). Of those, 10 factors showed P-values less than 0.05 and together explained 21.47% of the total variation in AK in our study population (Table 4 ). The four AK-associated CH SNP pairs together explained 4.37% of the AK variation (Table 4), which was 2.62 times more than the top-associated single SNPs (rs12203592 in IRF4, rs1805008 in MC1R, together explaining 1.67% of AK variation) identified in the previous conventional GWAS (Jacobs et al., 2015).

Although the previous AK study applied a conventional GWAS approach and identified two pigmentation genes associated with AK (Jacobs et al., 2015), in this study we used a genome-wide compound heterozygote scan and identified three new AK-associated loci harboring six genes currently not known to be involved in pigmentation. These three new genetic loci (6p21.2, 6p12.2, and 6q13) likely contain relaxed forms of compound heterozygote alleles conferring AK risk and provide reasonably good candidates for future experimental work to unveil their function regarding AK. They highlight six genes involved in the development of AK in a pairwise interactive fashion (KCNK5/KCNK17, PAQR8/GSTA2, KCNQ5/KHDC1). Of those six genes, three—KCNK5, KCNK17, and KCNQ5—encode potassium channel proteins and are involved in tumorigenesis in a wide range of tissue types including skin (Patel and Lazdunski, 2004; Williams et al., 2013). PAQR8 encodes membrane progestin receptor-β and is abundantly expressed in ovarian cancers (Charles et al., 2010). GSTA2 belongs to a superfamily of genes that encodes alpha class glutathione-S-transferases (GSTs). The alpha class GSTs are frequently found in the liver but have been characterized in extrahepatic epithelial tissues as well, such skin and lung (Del Boccio et al., 1987; Hirvonen et al., 1993). These enzymes exhibit glutathione peroxidase activity, thereby protecting the cells from reactive oxygen species and the products of peroxidation, and can alter responses in individuals exposed to reactive oxygen species due to environmental hazards like UV light (Desmots et al., 2001; Hayes and Pulford, 1995). UV plays a key role in the pathogenesis of AK, and one could hypothesize that impaired detoxification of reactive oxygen species could lead to a greater risk of (pre)malignant skin diseases. GSTA2 has not been linked to skin cancer as of yet, but GSTA4 was found to modify susceptibility to keratinocytic cancers (Abel et al., 2010). The candidate gene study detected significant CH interaction in SLC24A4, which encodes a potassium-dependent sodium/calcium exchanger. SLC24A4 is known to be involved in pigmentation (Schnetkamp, 2013) but was not significantly associated with AK in the previous conventional GWAS (P = 0.79) in contrast to SNPs in two other well-known pigmentation genes, MC1R and IRF4 (Jacobs et al., 2015).

Unlike what we found with the conventional GWAS previously applied to AK (Jacobs et al., 2015), none of the replicated AK-associated genes identified via genome-wide compound heterozygote scan in the current study is a known pigmentation gene. Finding nonpigmentation genes with involvement in AK is expected, considering the premalignant and complex phenotypic nature of AK. The compound heterozygote forms of the three pairs of SNPs we identified here in nonpigmentation genes explain a higher percentage of the AK variance than the two single SNPs from the two pigmentation genes we previously found (Jacobs et al., 2015). Furthermore, the targeted GCDH analysis performed in the 12 genomic regions harboring well-known pigmentation genes found an SNP pair in CH-like interaction near SLC24A4 with much stronger signal than that of the single-SNP analysis, which adds a third pigmentation gene to MC1R and IRF4, which we previously identified with AK association. We should emphasize that the pigmentation genes mentioned here should be acting on AK through melanogenesis-independent pathways as supported by two facts: first, other well-known pigmentation genes such as OCA2 and HERC2 were far from significant in their association with AK (Jacobs et al., 2015), and second, both the previous conventional AK GWAS and the current GCDH-based GWAS were adjusted for skin color.

We acknowledge that the sample size used in this study is not very large by the current GWAS practice; therefore, our study is likely underpowered, particularly for low-frequency variants (minor allele frequency < 1%), and for the same reason the replication rate is low (3/15 loci and 3/27 SNP pairs). Our replication dataset is of limited size and thus has limited power to prevent false negatives. The P-values of unreplicated SNP pairs were far from boarder-line significance; therefore, the effect directions and sizes provide limited information. In contrast, all significantly replicated SNP pairs had the same effect directions and similar effect sizes as the discovery dataset, as expected for a truly replicated signal. We conducted permutation analysis in the replication phase to guard against chance findings but still acknowledge that the possibility of false positives cannot be excluded, particularly because this is the first application of our new method. This limitation shall be overcome in future, much larger studies. Further, to reduce the computation burden in our genome-wide GCDH scan, we used a P-value filter to exclude all SNPs that do not have a strong-enough marginal effect (P > 0.1). This time-saving technique has the negative implication, however, that we may have missed those SNP pairs that do not associate with development of AK by themselves (with a small enough P-value) but may do so through CH-like interactions. Future studies performing genome-wide GCDH scans on the full dataset using suitably strong computational facilities will show whether this filtering approach indeed led to missing genetic risk factors for AK. Moreover, the default collapsing matrix, which renders binary-coded (0/2) collapsed genotypes, is used in the current study. Alternatively, we could also have used a different collapsing matrix that renders ternary-coded (0/1/2) collapsed genotypes, which could lead to new findings. As with conventional GWAS, it should be noted that for the SNP pairs we identified as significantly associated with AK using CollapsABEL, functional AK causality cannot necessarily be assumed because of linkage disequilibrium patterns at these genetic loci, neither for the highlighted genes nearby these SNP pairs.

The current study focused on the analysis of the effect of CH genotypes composed by two or more neighboring SNPs at the same locus, for which the biological mechanism has been well described in classical genetics. It would, however, be very interesting to try a similar genotype-collapsing approach to model the synergistic effects composed by two or more nonneighboring SNPs at different loci, although the underlying biological mechanism may be very different. Whether such an approach will improve the statistical power over the traditional regression-based synergistic effect modeling remains to be demonstrated.

In summary, an alternative GWAS approach based on CH-like interactions showed three to our knowledge previously unreported genetic loci associated with AK harboring nonpigmentation genes, which were not previously noted with the conventional GWAS approach that identified two pigmentation genes associated with AK. However, in keeping with the previous findings, our study also identified AK-associated CH-like interactions within a well-known pigmentation gene, which is different from the two pigmentation genes previously identified with AK association. Taken together, we present evidence that both pigmentation and nonpigmentation genes confer AK risk. Our results provide a noteworthy improvement in the percentage of AK variance explained and open up new research avenues for better understanding the molecular basis of this important skin disease in elderly Europeans. Additionally, our study delivers an empirical example that CollapsABEL and its underlying generalized collapsed double heterozygosity approach is useful in finding genes and DNA variants underlying human complex traits not detectable by the conventional GWAS approach. Our findings provide promises for future applications of CollapsABEL to other complex traits, including diseases with missing heritability observed via conventional GWAS in dermatology and other fields.

The RS is a prospective population-based dataset study of 14,926 participants, ages 45 years and older, living in a suburb of Rotterdam, The Netherlands. Details of the study design and population have been described elsewhere (Hofman et al., 2015). The RS has been approved by the Medical Ethics Committee of the Erasmus Medical Center and by the Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport of The Netherlands, implementing the Wet Bevolkingsonderzoek: ERGO (Population Studies Act: Rotterdam Study). All participants provided written informed consent to participate in the study and to have information obtained from their treating physicians. The RS was conducted according to the Declaration of Helsinki principles.

Skin AK and skin color were collected during a full-body skin examination at routine visits of the RS participants, as described in detail previously (Jacobs et al., 2015). In brief, AK data were collected as four severity levels: 0 (level 0), 1–3 (level 1, mild), 4–9 (level 2, moderate), and ≥10 (level 3, severe), and these four AK levels were considered as a continuous dependent variable in all subsequent analysis. We did not consider the AK counts directly, because individual AK lesions were not always “individual” but may confluence into one larger lesion, and the borders of the lesions are often not clearly visible. Skin color was also visually assessed during the skin examination using a 6-point scale: 1 = very white, 2 = white, 3 = white to olive, 4 = light brown, 5 = brown, and 6 = dark brown to black. The discovery dataset included 3,193 subjects collected up to November 2013, and the replication dataset included 624 subjects collected up to July 2014.

Whole blood DNA extraction, genotyping, quality controls, and 1000 Genomes Consortium 2012–based (Consortium GP, 2012) genotype imputation have been described in detail previously (Kreiner-Moller et al., 2015). In brief, genotyping was carried out using the Infinium II HumanHap550 BeadChips, version 3 (Illumina, San Diego, CA) and Human610-Quad BeadChips (Illumina, San Diego, CA). After all quality controls, the current study included a total of 6,043,271 autosomal SNPs (major allele frequency > 0.01, imputation R 2 > 0.3, SNP call rate > 0.95, p-value from Fisher's exact test for Hardy–Weinberg proportions > 1 × 10–3) in 3,817 individuals.

Our recently developed software CollapsABEL (Zhong et al., 2016) iteratively tests the association between a hypothetical genotype that is collapsed from a pair of SNPs and a phenotype (in this case AK) in a sliding window manner, that is, all nearby SNPs within a window of size k are collapsed and tested for association, then the window slides over the whole genome. Important parameters of CollapsABEL include window size k, P-value filter, and collapsing matrix. Window size determines the scope of SNP pairing, the P-value filter prunes all SNPs with weak marginal effect (having a P-value larger than the P-value filter), and the collapsing matrix defines the underlying genetic model for genotype collapsing. The default collapsing matrix represents the recessive model and output a binary pseudogenotype (0 or 2). In the present study of AK, we set k = 400 and P-value filter = 0.1, and we used the default collapsing matrix to achieve the optimal balance between SNP coverage and the affordable computational burden. After applying a P-value filter of 0.1 from the initial GWAS, there remained about 0.8 million SNPs for the subsequent CH GWAS. The CH GWAS conducted on average 195 tests per SNP (totaling 158 million tests), although the window size was set at 400. This is because the SNP pairs located further than 500 kbp were not tested. We applied the Bonferroni correction of 400 tests per SNP pair to be conservative; that is, we used P = 5×10–8/400 = 1.25×10–10 as the threshold for genome-wide significance. The GCDH testing for collapsed genotype and AK was based on linear modeling with sex, age, and skin color as covariates. Replication analysis for AK was conducted using the same linear model. Haplotypic configuration for each pair of SNPs was inferred using the R package haplo.stats (Sinnwell and Schaid, 2013). For a better interpretation of effect size (as increase in AK count), we also used an alternative coding for AK in both the discovery and replication phase for all highlighted SNP pairs—that is, in the linear modeling, we assign the AK count of 0, 2 (median = 1–3), 7 (median of 4–10), or 10 to participants belonging to each severity level instead of considering the four severity levels. Regional GCDH scans were conducted on region extracted from genomes starting from the first SNP and ending with the second SNP of the pair using a linear model with the same covariates as in the genome-wide scan, albeit without applying any P-value filter.

A candidate gene study was conducted targeting 12 genomic regions harboring 12 well-known pigmentation genes, selected on the basis of significant associations with hair, eye, and/or skin color in previous GWASs, including MC1R, HERC2, OCA2, ASIP, TYR, TYRP1, IRF4, SLC45A2, SLC24A5, TPCN1, KITLG, and BNC2 (Lamason et al., 2005; Liu et al., 2015; Sulem et al., 2007; Visser et al., 2014, 2015). We tested all pairs of SNPs within ±500 kbp of the top-associated SNP reported in previous pigmentation GWASs (the proband SNP) for CH-like association with AK, on the basis of linear modeling with sex, age, and skin color as covariates, conditioned on the genotype of the proband SNP in each region. We conducted a permutation analysis (number of permutations = 1,000) to empirically derive the significance threshold for the candidate gene study. For each permutation, 12 proband SNPs, together with their nearby SNPs (±500 kbp), were randomly selected from the genome. We then conducted the earlier-described association analysis, except that the AK phenotype was randomly shuffled, and the minimal P-value was obtained. The empirical significance threshold was defined as the 5% quantile of the 1,000 minimal P-values (P = 4.97 × 10–8), and the suggestive association was defined as the 50% of quantile (P = 6.21 × 10–6).

The multivariable analysis including age, sex, skin color, the 12 pigmentation SNPs, and the collapsed genotypes of the four SNP pairs was conducted in the combined dataset in an iterative manner to access the R 2 change due to individual factors using R scripting, that is, by adding one independent variable at a time to a linear model (lm function in R) in ascending order according to the P-values from the multivariable analysis including all independent variables; the R 2 estimated for the added independent variable is, then, the R 2 difference between the current model and a previous model.
The authors state no conflict of interest.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: We thank Pascal Arp, Mila Jhamai, Marijn Verkerk, Lizbeth Herrera, Marjolein Peters, and Carolina Medina-Gomez, for their help in creating the GWAS database, and Karol Estrada, Yurii Aulchenko, and Carolina Medina-Gomez, for the creation and analysis of imputed data. FL is supported by the Erasmus University Rotterdam fellowship and the Thousand Talents Program for Distinguished Young Scholars China.
